Find vector pointing left

Lets say I have two vectors
I want to find the vector which is pointing from right to left of the object.
Obviously, the vector is either [imath]cross(bottomToTop, footToHead)[/imath] or [imath](-1)* cross(bottomToTop, footToHead)[/imath] but I have not figured out to distinguish between the two. How would you do that?
As an illustration of the situation, please have a look at this picture:


I don't really understand your application, but if you want to determine the orientation of the vector resulting from the cross product, you can search up the well known "right-hand rule". When doing the right-hand rule, your thumb should point in the direction of [imath](bottomToTop \times footToHead)[/imath], so you can determine if that is the correct direction, or if you need to multiply by [imath](-1)[/imath] to correct it.
hi! yes, handedness actually came to my mind, but I have not figured out how to test the handedness programmatically.
What’s the difference between bottom-to-top and foot-to-head? They’re synonymous to me. An illustration of the situation might get you a usable answer.
@amd I have added an illustration, hope that clarifies things

You'd obviously want to scale such a vector, but if 'up' is positive [imath]x[/imath], 'forward' is positive [imath]y[/imath], and 'right' is positive 'z', then your vector should be [imath]- ( bottomToTop \times footToHead)[/imath].

OP's diagram (and the label "rightToLeft") suggest that left is "positive [imath]z[/imath]". ;)
It would seem that way, but I suspect that OP is working in some sort of graphics framework, in which case right is probably defined as 'positive z'.
